choices.text: 1 F(ab')₂ and a degraded Fc fragment
1 Variable chain and 1 constant chain

questions.text: When pepsin acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following are the end products? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 F(ab')₂ and a degraded Fc fragment

 

Explanation:

 

When pepsin acts on an immunoglobulin molecule, it cleaves below the disulfide bonds in the hinge region of the heavy chains. This results in the formation of one F(ab')₂ fragment, which contains both antigen-binding sites connected by disulfide bonds, and a degraded Fc fragment composed of smaller peptides.

 

Pepsin digestion differs from papain digestion, which cleaves above the disulfide bonds and produces two Fab fragments and one Fc fragment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments: Incorrect. This is the result of digestion with papain, not pepsin.

 

Option C. 1 Variable chain and 1 constant chain: Incorrect. This is not the result of enzymatic cleavage by either papain or pepsin.

 

Option D. 2 Fc and 2 Fab fragments: Incorrect. Such fragmentation is not observed with enzymatic digestion of immunoglobulins.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Herpes-simplex virus

questions.text: Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus are caused by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes-simplex virus

 

Infection with the Herpes simplex virus (HS) causes punched-out ulcers in the esophagus.

 

Immunocompromised patients are more likely to develop HS esophagitis.

 

Endoscopic findings may include multiple discrete or coalescent small ulcers that appear superficial, punched out, or volcano-like.

 

 

For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer. The following microscopic findings are seen here:

 

  • Ballooning degeneration
  • Ground-glass changes in nuclei
  • Infected squamous epithelial cells show 3 M’s:
    • Molding of nuclear contours
    • Margination of chromatin to the periphery of nuclei
    • Multinucleation
  • Intranuclear inclusions:
    • Cowdry type A: acidophilic inclusion with surrounding clear halo
    • Equivocal cases require an HSV immunohistochemical (IHC) stain to confirm the diagnosis

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Causes larger, shallow ulcers and might involve deeper tissue layers, with "owl's eye" inclusions typically seen.

 

Option C. Candida: Presents typically as white plaques or linear fissures rather than punched-out ulcers.

 

Option D. Acid: Causes erosive esophagitis with continuous areas of inflammation rather than discrete ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus causes distinctive punched-out ulcers in the esophagus, particularly noted in immunocompromised patients, diagnosed by endoscopic appearance and confirmed via histopathological findings.

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their genetic abnormalities. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

 

HUNTINGTON CHOREA

questions.text: Which of the following is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) NRG-1

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are mesenchymal tumors that commonly present with gastrointestinal bleeding. They are characterized by mutations that lead to the overactivity of tyrosine kinase. The most common mutation associated with GISTs is in the CKIT gene, which leads to the activation of the KIT receptor tyrosine kinase.

 

NRG-1 (Neuregulin 1):

 

NRG-1 is a gene that is part of the epidermal growth factor receptor family. It is not associated with GISTs. Instead, NRG-1 is implicated in the pathogenesis of mental health disorders, such as schizophrenia. Therefore, it is not used as a marker for GISTs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. KIT: KIT mutations are the most common genetic alterations found in GISTs and are critical for the diagnosis and treatment of these tumors.

 

Option B. PDGFR: Mutations in the PDGFR gene occur in a subset of GISTs and play a role similar to KIT mutations in tumor development.

 

Option C. SDH: SDH mutations are linked to Carney-Stratakis syndrome and are significant markers in a subset of GISTs. These mutations lead to defects in cellular respiration and are associated with the development of GISTs and paragangliomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NRG-1 is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors. The primary markers for GISTs include KIT, PDGFR, and SDH mutations.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient on immunosuppressive therapy presents with cough, fever, and pneumonia. A biopsy reveals the cells shown in the image. Which organism is responsible for this finding? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CMV (Cytomegalovirus)

 

The image provided shows cells with the characteristic "owl eye" appearance, which is a classic histopathological finding in infections caused by Cytomegalovirus (CMV). CMV is a type of herpesvirus that can cause severe infections, especially in immunocompromised patients, such as those on immunosuppressive therapy.

 

The "owl eye" appearance refers to the large intranuclear inclusion bodies surrounded by a clear halo, resembling an owl's eye. This appearance is due to the replication of the virus within the nucleus of the infected cell, leading to the formation of these inclusion bodies. In CMV infections, both intranuclear and intracytoplasmic basophilic inclusions can be observed, which is a key diagnostic feature.

 

CMV commonly causes pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS, organ transplant recipients, or patients on immunosuppressive therapy. The virus can also cause other severe complications, including retinitis, colitis, and encephalitis.

 

Note – Ganciclovir - Preferred antiviral medication for treating CMV infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pox virus: Poxviruses, such as the variola virus (which causes smallpox), typically produce skin lesions and are not known for causing the "owl eye" appearance in cells. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option C. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): EBV is associated with conditions such as infectious mononucleosis and certain lymphomas, like Burkitt's lymphoma. It does not typically produce the "owl eye" inclusions seen in CMV infection, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Chickenpox (Varicella-Zoster Virus): Chickenpox, caused by the varicella-zoster virus, is characterized by vesicular skin lesions and does not produce the "owl eye" appearance in histological sections. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "owl eye" appearance of cells in a biopsy is a hallmark of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, particularly in immunocompromised patients. This feature is crucial for diagnosing CMV-related complications, such as CMV pneumonia.

choices.text: Carcinoid tumor
Gastrointestinal stromal tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is an epithelial tumor of the stomach? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gastric adenocarcinoma

 

Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the stomach.

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy (90% cases) of the stomach.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid tumor: This is a neuroendocrine tumor.

 

Option B. Lymphoma: Represents a type of blood cancer originating from lymphocytes.

 

Option C. Gastrointestinal stromal tumor: A non-epithelial tumor that arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is the phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genomic imprinting

 

Genomic Imprinting is the phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents.

 

Important functional differences exist between the paternal allele and the maternal allele. These differences result from an epigenetic process, called imprinting. In most cases, imprinting selectively inactivates either the maternal or paternal allele. Thus, maternal imprinting refers to transcriptional silencing of the maternal allele, whereas paternal imprinting implies that the paternal allele is inactivated.

 

Genomic imprinting is a process of silencing genes through DNA methylation. The repressed allele is methylated, while the active allele is unmethylated.

 

E.g., Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome. Both of these syndromes can be caused by imprinting or other errors involving genes on the long arm of chromosome 15.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gonadal mosaicism: Gonadal mosaicism refers to the presence of more than one genetically distinct cell line within the gonads. This can lead to different genetic outcomes in offspring but does not involve the differential effect of the same gene based on parental origin. Therefore, it is not related to genomic imprinting.

 

Option C. Anticipation: Anticipation is a phenomenon where a genetic disorder appears earlier and with increased severity in successive generations. This is different from genomic imprinting, as it does not involve the differential effects of a gene based on whether it is inherited from the mother or the father.

 

Option D. Incomplete penetrance: Incomplete penetrance occurs when not all individuals carrying a disease-causing mutation exhibit the disease phenotype. This concept is unrelated to the differential effect of a gene based on its parental origin and does not describe genomic imprinting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genomic imprinting is an epigenetic process where the same gene can have different effects depending on whether it is inherited from the mother or the father, typically through mechanisms like DNA methylation.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 328

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents with a midline neck swelling that moves on deglutition. Ultrasound revealed a 2 cm x 2 cm nodule on the left lobe of the thyroid, extending into the strap muscles. The histopathology image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Papillary cancer of thyroid

 

The clinical scenario and the image showing papillae lined by cells with overlapping nuclei and Orphan Annie eye nuclei indicate a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of thyroid.

 

Histologically, the following features are present

 

  1. Papillary pattern - Papillae composed of fibrovascular stalk and covered by single layer of tumor cells is the predominant feature. Papillae are often accompanied by follicles.
  2. Tumor cells. The tumor cells have characteristic nuclear features due to dispersed nuclear chromatin imparting it ground glass or optically clear appearance and clear or oxyphilic cytoplasm also called Orphan Annie nuclei.
  3. Invasion - Invade the capsule and intra-thyroid lymphatics
  4. Psammoma bodies - Small, concentric, calcified spherules called psammoma bodies in the stroma.

 

Papillary carcinoma thyroid microscopy shows branching papillae having fibrovascular stalk covered by a single layer of cuboidal cells having ground nuclei. Colloid-filled follicles and sloid sheets of tumor cells are present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary cancer of thyroid: This cancer arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid and is associated with elevated calcitonin levels. Histologically, it shows a solid growth pattern with amyloid deposits, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

Option B. Follicular cancer of thyroid: This type of thyroid cancer typically shows a follicular growth pattern with invasion into blood vessels or the capsule. The cells do not have the distinct nuclear features (Orphan Annie nuclei) seen in papillary carcinoma.

 

Option C. Thyroglossal cyst: This is a benign cystic lesion that usually presents as a midline neck mass that moves with swallowing or tongue protrusion. It does not present with a nodule in the thyroid gland or the histological features described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is characterized by Orphan Annie nuclei, psammoma bodies, and a papillary architecture, which are key diagnostic features.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with bleeding disorder, gives family history of her father and sister suffering from the same bleeding disorders. Which is the most likely disorder? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Von Willebrand disease

 

Von Willebrand disease is a common inherited bleeding disorder that affects both males and females, and it is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means that males and females have an equal chance of inheriting the disorder from a parent, which is consistent with the family history provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemophilia A: This is a X-linked recessive disorder primarily affecting males; females are typically carriers unless under rare circumstances.

 

Option C. Christmas Disease (Hemophilia B): Similar to Hemophilia A, this condition is also X-linked recessive, predominantly affecting males.

 

Option D. Factor 12 Deficiency: This is a much rarer condition and usually does not lead to significant bleeding issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Willebrand disease is characterized by its autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and affects both genders, making it the most likely diagnosis for a female patient with a family history of bleeding disorders involving both male and female family members.

questions.text: A patient had a pulmonary mass which shows IHC staining with TTF-1 as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma lung

 

Thyroid Transcription Factor-1 (TTF-1) is a nuclear protein that is a specific marker for adenocarcinoma of the lung and small cell carcinoma of the lung. However, it is most commonly associated with adenocarcinoma.

 

TTF-1 positivity indicates that the tumor cells are likely of lung or thyroid origin, with adenocarcinoma being the most common type of lung cancer associated with this marker.

 

Additionally, other markers like Napsin A and surfactant protein A1 are also specific to adenocarcinoma of the lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell cancer lung: Squamous cell carcinoma typically shows markers like P63, P40, or keratin. It does not stain positive for TTF-1, differentiating it from adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Small cell carcinoma lung: While TTF-1 can be positive in small cell carcinoma, other specific markers such as chromogranin, synaptophysin, and INSM-1 are more indicative. TTF-1's presence alone, along with the given context, makes adenocarcinoma the more likely diagnosis.

 

Option D. Large cell carcinoma lung: This is generally a diagnosis of exclusion and does not have specific immunohistochemical markers like TTF-1. Large cell carcinoma is generally a diagnosis of exclusion, as it lacks specific markers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TTF-1 is a key immunohistochemical marker that strongly suggests adenocarcinoma of the lung, particularly when observed in a pulmonary mass.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of hematuria. Upon examination, he is found to be normotensive and has pedal edema. Further investigations reveal a lack of glycosuria and a creatinine level of 9. A renal biopsy is performed, and the results are shown below. Which of the following investigations should be conducted to identify the underlying disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti GBM antibodies

 

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPG) is suspected based on the clinical history and microscopy showing crescents. Among the options presented, anti-GBM antibody testing should be performed because it is part of the RPGN work-up. 

 

HISTOLOGY:

 

Glomeruli — Regardless of the underlying cause, all forms of RPGN exhibit pathognomonic 'crescents' on the inside of Bowman's capsules. Crescents compress the glomerular tuft and obliterate the Bowman's space.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANA: Antinuclear antibody (ANA) testing is used for diagnosing autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which is more typically associated with Type II RPGN. It is not the primary investigation for Type I RPGN.

 

Option C. HIV RNA: This test is used for detecting HIV infection. While HIV can cause kidney disease, it is not specifically associated with the pathology seen in this case.

 

Option D. Urine immunoelectrophoresis: This test is used to detect abnormal proteins in the urine, such as in multiple myeloma. It is not relevant for diagnosing RPGN, specifically Type I RPGN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testing for anti-GBM antibodies is crucial in the diagnosis of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) with crescents on histology, particularly for identifying Type I RPGN (anti-GBM disease).

questions.text: Which of the following is not usually involved in the immunohistochemistry of acute lymphoblastic leukemia? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cytokeratin

 

Cytokeratin is not a marker of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It is an epithelial cell marker for thymoma.

 

Immunophenotype in ALL –

 

  • Terminal deoxynucleotidyl-transferase (TdT), a specialized DNA polymerase, is positive in more than 95% of cases.
  • Lymphoblasts usually express the pan B-cell marker CD19 and the transcription factor PAX5, as well as CD10.
  • More mature “late pre-B” ALLs express CD10, CD19, CD20, and cytoplasmic IgM heavy chain (μ chain).
  • T-ALLs are arrested at various stages of pre-T cell development. In most cases the cells are positive for CD1, CD2, CD5, and CD7.
  • “Late” pre-T cell tumors are positive CD3, CD4, and CD8

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TdT: A highly specific marker for ALL, present in over 95% of cases.

 

Option B. CD1a: Commonly expressed in T-ALL, particularly in early T-cell development stages.

 

Option C. CD3: A marker for T-cell lineage, used in identifying T-ALL and distinguishing it from B-cell lineage ALL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cytokeratin is not a marker for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and is instead an epithelial cell marker used in identifying epithelial tumors such as thymoma.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 111

questions.text: On a histopathological slide of an atherosclerotic plaque, what does the presence of needle-shaped empty spaces indicate? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Cholesterol Cleft

 

Explanation: 

 

In atherosclerotic plaques, the characteristic needle-shaped empty spaces observed on histopathology represent cholesterol clefts. These spaces form when cholesterol crystals are dissolved during routine tissue processing, leaving behind characteristic empty clefts. They are typically found in the necrotic core of the atherosclerotic plaque, alongside foam cells, necrotic debris, fibrin, and other plasma proteins. These crystalline cholesterol deposits contribute to the "grumous" (soft and friable) nature of the lipid core in advanced atheromas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foam Cells - These are lipid-laden macrophages and smooth muscle cells found in atherosclerotic plaques, but they appear as cells with foamy cytoplasm due to accumulated lipid droplets, not as empty needle-shaped spaces. Foam cells are a key feature of atherosclerotic lesions, particularly in early fatty streaks.

 

Option C. Smooth Muscle Cells - These cells are present in atherosclerotic plaques, particularly in the fibrous cap, but they appear as spindle-shaped cells with nuclei, not as empty spaces. Smooth muscle cells play an important role in plaque stabilization through ECM production.

 

Option D. Glycogen - Glycogen deposits appear as clear spaces within cell cytoplasm but have a different morphology than cholesterol clefts and are not typically a prominent feature of atherosclerotic plaques. Glycogen is more commonly observed in glycogen storage diseases or in certain liver pathologies.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cholesterol clefts, appearing as characteristic needle-shaped empty spaces in histopathology, are hallmark features of advanced atherosclerotic plaques, representing crystalline cholesterol deposits that have been dissolved during tissue processing.

choices.text: Aschoff body; Rheumatic heart disease
Calcification of valve; Mitral stenosis

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of dyspnea on exertion for 1 month. Echocardiography showed the presence of mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy. Identify the histopathological finding given below and the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aschoff body; Rheumatic heart disease

 

The lesion shown in the histopathological slide is Aschoff's body and the most probable diagnosis is rheumatic heart disease (RHD).

 

Aschoff's bodies have the following components:

 

  • Anitschkow cells or plump macrophages
  • Abundant cytoplasm
  • Caterpillar cells - refer to centrally condensed chromatin into slender, wavy ribbons
  • Foci of fibrinoid necrosis
  • Aschoff's giant cells - multinucleated larger macrophages
  • T-cells
  • Plasma cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcification of valve; Mitral stenosis: While mitral stenosis can result from calcification, it is more typically associated with chronic rheumatic heart disease, which involves Aschoff bodies rather than calcification alone.

 

Option C. Granuloma; Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas, but it does not present with Aschoff bodies.

 

Option D. Non-caseating granuloma: Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis typically presents with caseating granulomas, not Aschoff bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aschoff bodies are indicative of Rheumatic heart disease (RHD), and their presence supports the diagnosis in a patient with clinical features such as mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1044

choices.text: Type I vWD presents with severe bleeding since birth
Type II vWD has reduced activity of von Willebrand factor
Type III vWD has very low levels of von Willebrand factor
Type III vWD presents clinically as a severe disease

questions.text: Which of the following is false about von Willebrand disease? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type I vWD presents with severe bleeding since birth

 

Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder and is classified into three main types: Type I, Type II, and Type III.

 

  • Type I vWD is the most common form and is characterized by a mild reduction in the quantity of von Willebrand factor (vWF). It typically presents with mild to moderate mucocutaneous bleeding rather than severe bleeding from birth, making option A false.
  • Type II vWD involves a qualitative defect of vWF, leading to reduced activity rather than quantity, and presents with moderate bleeding tendencies.
  • Type III vWD is the most severe form, with very low levels or complete absence of vWF, leading to severe bleeding symptoms. This type is rare but clinically severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type II vWD has reduced activity of von Willebrand factor: This statement is true as Type II vWD is characterized by a functional defect in the von Willebrand factor, affecting its activity rather than the amount.

 

Option C. Type III vWD has very low levels of von Willebrand factor: This is correct; Type III vWD is associated with very low or absent levels of vWF, causing severe bleeding tendencies.

 

Option D. Type III vWD presents clinically as a severe disease: This is true. Due to extremely low levels of vWF, Type III vWD is associated with severe clinical manifestations, including spontaneous bleeding episodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type I von Willebrand disease presents with mild to moderate bleeding and is the least severe form, contrasting with Type III, which has very low vWF levels and presents as a severe disease.

choices.text: Lung cancer
Bladder cancer

questions.text: A patient with occupational exposure to benzene presents with repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature. This occupational exposure will predispose him to which of the following cancers? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leukemia

 

Benzene exposure at work increases the risk of developing leukemia. The clinical history of repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening temperature rise with benzene exposure points to leukemia.

 

Hepatic CYP2E1 converts benzene to an epoxide. The epoxide and other metabolites disrupt bone marrow progenitor cell differentiation, resulting in marrow aplasia and acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML), acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL), chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), multiple myeloma, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma have all been linked to benzene exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lung Cancer: Exposure to arsenic and its compounds, asbestos, beryllium and its compounds, chromium compounds, nickel compounds, radon, and its decay products can cause lung cancer.

 

Option C. Bladder Cancer: Exposure to aryl amines, particularly 2-naphthylamine and related compounds, cyclophosphamide, cigarette smoking, irradiation can cause bladder cancer.

 

Option D. Skin Cancer: Exposure to UV rays, arsenic, and its compounds can cause skin cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Occupational exposure to benzene predisposes individuals to leukemia, as benzene metabolites disrupt bone marrow progenitor cell differentiation, leading to marrow aplasia and various types of leukemia. The clinical presentation of repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature in a patient with benzene exposure is highly suggestive of leukemia.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with abdominal pain, jaundice and weight loss. He has hypoglycemia and elevated alpha fetoprotein levels (250IU) but has normal AST and ALT. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis of the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatocellular carcinoma

 

A history of chronic alcohol intake with abdominal pain, jaundice and weight loss is suggestive of a liver dysfunction.  

 

 

Other Options:

 

Differential Diagnosis:

 

Option A. Liver cirrhosis: Often has elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT) and may present with similar symptoms but is not typically associated with high AFP levels.

 

Option B. Hepatitis: Would show elevated AST and ALT levels, ruling out this option.

 

Option D. Cholangiocarcinoma: May present with jaundice and weight loss but is not typically associated with elevated AFP levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocellular carcinoma should be considered in a chronic alcoholic presenting with abdominal pain, jaundice, weight loss, hypoglycemia, and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels, especially with normal AST and ALT levels.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Faggot cell

 

The picture shows multiple Auer rods clustered in a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks.

 

Such cells are called faggot cells (faggot meaning bundle of sticks in French). Faggot cells are characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) associated with the t(15;17) translocation.

 

The presence of faggot cells is particularly indicative of APL, where the leukemic promyelocytes have an abundance of Auer rods. Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules formed by the fusion of primary (azurophilic) granules. While Auer rods can be seen in other subtypes of AML, the clustering of these rods within a single cell to form a faggot cell is most commonly associated with APL.

 

Since the question is particularly about the cell, the best answer from the given options is faggot cell and not Auer rods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auer rods: Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules present in many cases but particularly numerous in AML with the t(15;17) aberration (acute promyelocytic leukemia).

 

Option B. Flaming promyelocyte: Flaming promyelocyte is an abnormal promyelocyte with disintegrating cytoplasm and liberating Auer rods and granules into the surrounding marrow. Found in APL

 

Option C. Dusky promyelocyte: Promyelocytes with fine granules appearing dusky or hazy are called dusky promyelocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A faggot cell, characterized by multiple Auer rods clustered together in a single cell, is highly indicative of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). While Auer rods are a feature of various forms of AML, the presence of faggot cells is particularly associated with APL.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 1154

questions.text: Which of the following is the pattern of inheritance with the pedigree chart provided in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mitochondrial inheritance

 

The pedigree chart provided in the image demonstrates a pattern of inheritance where an affected female passes the trait or disease to all of her offspring, regardless of their gender. Additionally, the affected males do not pass the trait to any of their offspring. This pattern is characteristic of mitochondrial inheritance, also known as maternal inheritance.

 

Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is inherited exclusively from the mother because mitochondria in the sperm are typically not involved in fertilization. Therefore, any mutations in mitochondrial DNA will be passed from an affected mother to all of her children. However, because males do not contribute mitochondria to their offspring, they do not pass on mitochondrial diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal recessive: Autosomal recessive inheritance typically requires both parents to carry one copy of the mutated gene, and it affects both males and females equally. The pattern in the pedigree, where all children of an affected female are affected, does not fit an autosomal recessive pattern.

 

Option B. Autosomal dominant: Autosomal dominant inheritance usually involves a 50% chance of passing the mutated gene from an affected parent to each child, regardless of gender. The pedigree showing all offspring of an affected female being affected, while none of the offspring of an affected male are affected, does not fit this pattern.

 

Option C. X-linked recessive: X-linked recessive inheritance usually affects males more frequently, as they have only one X chromosome. Affected males would pass the mutated gene to all of their daughters (who would be carriers) but none of their sons. This pattern does not match the pedigree chart provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by the transmission of a trait from an affected mother to all of her offspring, while affected males do not pass the trait to their children. This unique pattern is due to the inheritance of mitochondrial DNA, which is maternally inherited.

 

Example of Maternal/ mitochondrial inheritance diseases: Leber's Optic Neuropathy, MELAS Syndrome (Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like manifestation).

questions.text: Identify the mode of inheritance from the pedigree chart given below: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal dominant

 

The pedigree chart given is suggestive of an autosomal dominant Disorders

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Autosomal dominant inheritance is characterized by a consistent appearance of affected individuals in every generation, with no sex bias and manifestation in individuals who carry one copy of the mutant allele.

questions.text: Alpha 1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elastase

 

Alpha 1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme neutrophil elastase.

 

On serum electrophoresis, alpha-1-antitrypsin (-1-AT), also known as alpha 1-protease inhibitor, is a glycoprotein that typically makes up the alpha1-globulin fraction of the plasma proteins.

 

It is typically produced in the liver and found in macrophages, circulating blood, and tissue fluids.

 

The name "Alpha1-protease inhibitor" comes from the fact that alpha1AT's primary role in the body is to inhibit proteases. The proteases, particularly the elastases, come from neutrophils.

 

The anti-elastase activity of alpha1-AT prevents neutrophil elastase from digesting lung parenchyma, despite its ability to do so.

 

In the proteinase inhibitor (Pi) locus on chromosome 14, co-dominantly expressed genes that code for 1-antitrypsin are located. The Pi locus has a wide variety of alleles and is highly polymorphic.

 

Those who have the alpha1-AT deficit develop panacinar pulmonary emphysema.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase: Not primarily inhibited by A1AT; it is an antioxidant enzyme.

 

Option B. Collagenase: Also not a primary target of A1AT; these enzymes break down collagen in connective tissue.

 

Option D. Phospholipase: Not inhibited by A1AT; involved in the hydrolysis of phospholipids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha 1-antitrypsin's critical role is to inhibit neutrophil elastase, thus protecting connective tissue from inflammatory damage, particularly in the lungs and liver.

choices.text: Cell cycle will stop at G2
Cell cycle will stop at G1
There will be no effect on cell cycle as RB gene phosphorylation is not needed
The cell cycle progresses and cell divides

questions.text: If the RB gene is hypophosphorylated, which of the following will happen? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cell cycle will stop at G1

 

If the retinoblastoma (RB) gene is hypophosphorylated, then cell cycle will stop at G1.

 

The Rb protein is a tumor suppressor, which plays a pivotal role in the negative control of the cell cycle and in tumor progression. It has been shown that Rb protein (pRb) is responsible for a major G1 checkpoint, blocking S-phase entry and cell growth by binding to and inactivating a transcription factor (E2F). The phosphorylation of RB results in the release of E2F activating gene transcription and cell-cycle progression occurs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cell cycle will stop at G2: This is incorrect because the Rb protein specifically regulates the G1 to S phase transition, not the G2 phase.

 

Option C. There will be no effect on cell cycle as RB gene phosphorylation is not needed: This is incorrect. The phosphorylation state of the Rb protein is crucial for its function in regulating the cell cycle. Hypophosphorylated Rb actively suppresses cell cycle progression at G1.

 

Option D. The cell cycle progresses and cell divides: This is incorrect because the hypophosphorylated form of Rb prevents the cell from progressing past the G1 phase, thereby halting cell division.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hypophosphorylated state of the Rb protein prevents the cell cycle from progressing past the G1 phase by binding to and inactivating E2F, thereby acting as a crucial checkpoint in preventing uncontrolled cell proliferation.

questions.text:
Which mediators involved in the early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity? (AIIMS MAY 2021)

 

  1. Mast cell
  2. Histamine
  3. Neutrophils
  4. Prostaglandins
  5. Leukotrienes
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Type 1 hypersensitivity reactions, also known as immediate hypersensitivity reactions, are typically triggered by allergens and involve the rapid release of mediators from mast cells. The early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity involves several key mediators:

 

  • Mast cells (1): Play a central role in initiating the reaction. When IgE antibodies on the surface of mast cells bind to an allergen, the mast cells degranulate, releasing various mediators.
  • Histamine (2): One of the primary mediators released from mast cells, responsible for many of the acute symptoms of allergic reactions, such as vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, and smooth muscle contraction.
  • Prostaglandins (4): Specifically, Prostaglandin D2 (PGD2), is produced by mast cells and contributes to vasodilation, bronchoconstriction, and increased mucus secretion.
  • Leukotrienes (5): Specifically, Leukotrienes C4 and D4 are potent mediators that cause prolonged bronchoconstriction, increased vascular permeability, and mucus production.

 

Other Option:

 

Neutrophils (3), while involved in various immune responses, are not typically considered mediators of the early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity. They are more associated with later phases of inflammation or other types of immune responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early phase of type 1 hypersensitivity involves Mast cells, Histamine, Prostaglandins (D2) and Leukotrienes (C4 and D4).

 

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 377

questions.text: In which of the following processes does one cell engulf another cell without degrading it? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Emperipolesis

 

Explanation:

 

Emperipolesis is the process in which one cell actively enters another cell but remains intact without being degraded. Unlike entosis, in which the engulfed cell is digested by the host cell, emperipolesis allows the engulfed cell to persist and sometimes exit the host cell later. This phenomenon is seen in physiological and pathological processes, such as in immune surveillance or during interactions between cancer and immune cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Necrosis: Incorrect. Necrosis is an uncontrolled form of cell death due to injury or damage, leading to cell lysis and inflammation. It does not involve a cell-in-cell appearance.

 

Option B. Apoptosis: Incorrect. Apoptosis is a programmed form of cell death characterized by apoptotic bodies and phagocytosis of the remnants, but it does not involve a cell-in-cell structure.

 

Option D. Entosis: Incorrect. Entosis is a process where one cell actively engulfs another cell, leading to its degradation within lysosomes, creating a characteristic "cell-in-cell" appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emperipolesis is distinct from other processes like entosis, as it involves the engulfment of one cell into another without degradation. Understanding this phenomenon is crucial in identifying its roles in immune regulation and pathological conditions like cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is protective against Alzheimer’s disease? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Apo E2

 

Explanation:

 

Apolipoprotein E2 (Apo E2) is associated with a decreased risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease. It is believed to have a protective effect due to its role in promoting the efficient clearance of amyloid-beta from the brain, which is a key pathological feature of Alzheimer's disease. Among the ApoE alleles, ApoE2 has the lowest affinity for amyloid-beta and is less likely to contribute to plaque formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo E1: Incorrect. Apo E1 is not commonly associated with Alzheimer’s disease or its risk profile.

 

Option C. Apo E3: Incorrect. Apo E3 is the most prevalent allele in the population and is considered neutral in terms of Alzheimer’s disease risk.

 

Option D. Apo E4: Incorrect. Apo E4 is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease, increasing both the risk and the severity of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While Apo E4 increases the risk of Alzheimer’s disease, Apo E2 is protective due to its role in reducing amyloid-beta accumulation in the brain. Understanding the roles of ApoE alleles in Alzheimer’s disease can inform genetic counseling and research on therapeutic interventions.

choices.text: Ewing's sarcoma

questions.text: All are small round blue cell tumors except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemangioblastoma

 

Hemangioblastoma is not a small round blue cell tumor.

 

Many childhood tumors have been collectively referred to as small round blue cell tumors due to their primitive histologic appearance.

 

The differential diagnosis of such tumors includes neuroblastoma, Wilms tumor, lymphoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor, medulloblastoma and retinoblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a classic example of a small round blue cell tumor. It is a highly malignant tumor that primarily affects bone and soft tissues, particularly in children and young adults.

 

Option C. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a small round blue cell tumor of the eye, commonly seen in children. It is characterized by the presence of small, undifferentiated cells with hyperchromatic nuclei.

 

Option D. Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is another example of a small round blue cell tumor. It arises from neural crest cells and is most commonly found in the adrenal glands or along the sympathetic chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemangioblastoma is not classified as a small round blue cell tumor, unlike Ewing's sarcoma, retinoblastoma, and neuroblastoma.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 882

questions.text: Most common indication for elective splenectomy is? (FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immune thrombocytopenia

 

Most common indication for elective splenectomy is Immune thrombocytopenia. Splenectomy is performed when patients do not respond to medical therapy. ITP is an autoimmune disorder characterized by a low platelet count and increased risk of bleeding. The spleen is responsible for the destruction of platelets, and its removal helps to increase platelet count and reduce the risk of bleeding.

 

Indications for elective splenectomy include:

  • Hereditary Spherocytosis
  • Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
  • Thalassemia:
  • Hypersplenism
  • Splenic Tumors or Cysts
  • Splenic Abscess or Infarction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hereditary spherocytosis: While splenectomy is indicated in this condition, it is not the most common indication compared to ITP.

 

Option B. G6PD deficiency: Splenectomy is not a typical treatment for G6PD deficiency, which is managed by avoiding oxidative stress.

 

Option D. Sickle cell anemia: Splenectomy may be performed in some cases of sickle cell disease, but it is not the most common indication compared to ITP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common indication for elective splenectomy is Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP).

choices.text: Cells don't lyse in hypotonic solution

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spherical cells may be seen

 

G6PD deficiency can have spherical red cells.

 

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD. is an enzyme that helps in the synthesis of NADPH. NADPH helps in keeping glutathione in a reduced state (GSH). This reduced glutathione acts as a defense against oxidative damage.

 

In G6PD deficiency, RBCs are exposed to oxidants. These cross-linking of the reactive sulfhydryl groups in the globin chain of hemoglobin. These are then deposited as inclusions in RBC membranes as Heinz bodies. When these RBCs pass-through spleen, macrophages pluck out these membrane inclusions. The remaining cells are seen as bite cells. Less severely damaged cells lose a part of their membrane, forming spherocytes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spectrin: Spectrin is a part of the RBC membrane skeleton. It is commonly defective in hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Cells don't lyse in hypotonic solution: Normal biconcave RBCs have a bit of an 'extra space'. They can accommodate a little fluid when exposed to a hypotonic solution. But spherocytes have already lost a part of its membrane, so are relatively full. Hence if they are placed in a hypotonic solution, they absorb more fluid and result in lysis of RBCs. This forms the basis of testing spherocytes in Hereditary spherocytosis or G6PD and is known as osmotic fragility testing.

 

Option D. Cells lyse in hypertonic solution: Placing RBCs in a hypertonic solution causes them to lose water and shrink, but significant hemolysis does not typically occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

What is G6PD Deficiency?

 

  • A genetic enzymopathy, inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.
  • G6PD is an enzyme in the pentose phosphate pathway that generates NADPH, which helps maintain reduced glutathione (GSH).
  • GSH protects red blood cells (RBCs) from oxidative damage.

 

What Happens in G6PD Deficiency?

 

  • Without enough G6PD, RBCs are vulnerable to oxidative stress, such as:
    • Infections
    • Drugs (e.g., sulfa drugs, antimalarials)
    • Fava beans

 

Key peripheral smear findings:

 

  • Bite cells
  • Heinz bodies

 

In glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, red blood cells become spherical (spherocytes) due to oxidative damage and the removal of damaged membrane by the spleen, leading to hemolytic anemia.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1198-1199

choices.text: Urine specimen is used
Sanger sequencing is used
Study of fluid in tumor microenvironment
DNA is collected in micro vessels

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding liquid-based cytology? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine specimen is used

 

Liquid-based cytology can also be done using a urine specimen. It is commonly used in cervical cancer screening in place of a pap smear.

 

Liquid-based cytology is a method of preparing samples for examination in cytopathology. The sample is collected, normally by a small brush, in the same way as for a conventional smear test, but rather than the smear being transferred directly to a microscope slide, the sample is deposited into a small bottle of preservative liquid. At the laboratory, the liquid is treated to remove other elements such as mucus before a layer of cells is placed on a slide.

 

Liquid-based cytology uses:

 

  • Used in place of PAP smear for cervical screening (most common use)
  • Thyroid cyst fluid examination.
  • Oral lesions
  • Body fluids sampling (e.g., urine, pleural effusions), brushing samples (e.g. gastrointestinal tract, lung), and fine needle aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sanger sequencing is used: Sanger sequencing is a method of DNA sequencing and is not related to liquid-based cytology.

 

Option C. Study of fluid in tumor microenvironment: Liquid-based cytology is not specifically focused on the study of tumor microenvironment fluids; rather, it is a method for preparing and analyzing cellular samples.

 

Option D. DNA is collected in micro vessels: This is not a description of liquid-based cytology but may relate to other molecular biology techniques.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liquid-based cytology can use urine specimens, among others, to prepare samples for cytological examination, offering advantages over traditional smear techniques in terms of sample preservation and clarity.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with anemia and hemoglobinuria. Investigations reveal increased lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). The peripheral smear image is given below. Which of the following physical examination findings can support the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mechanical second heart sound

 

The above scenario, which includes anemia, increased LDH, and hemoglobinuria, as well as schistocytes on a peripheral smear, is suggestive of angiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) caused by red cell trauma. A mechanical second heart sound can help to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia is a type of hemolytic anemia caused by red cell trauma.

 

Shear forces cause hemolysis in artificial mechanical cardiac valves due to turbulent blood flow and pressure gradients. This traumatic damage causes intravascular hemolysis and the appearance in blood smears of red cell fragments (schistocytes), burr cells, helmet cells, and triangle cells. The same pressure gradients are also responsible for a mechanical heart sound on auscultation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenomegaly: Splenomegaly is often seen in various hemolytic anemias but is not specific for MAHA associated with mechanical heart valves.

 

Option B. Frontal bossing: Frontal bossing is seen in congenital hemolytic anemias such as thalassemia and sickle cell anemia due to extramedullary hematopoiesis, but not typically in MAHA.

 

Option D. Goitre: Goitre is related to thyroid disorders and is not associated with hemolytic anemia or mechanical heart valves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with anemia, hemoglobinuria, increased LDH, and schistocytes on a peripheral smear, the presence of a mechanical second heart sound can support the diagnosis of angiopathic hemolytic anemia due to mechanical heart valves. The mechanical destruction of red blood cells leads to intravascular hemolysis, characteristic laboratory findings, and specific physical examination findings related to the heart valve.

choices.text: Intact cell organelle
Altered cell shape
Enzyme mediated degradation
Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change

questions.text: Which of the following is not helpful for differentiating between necrosis and apoptosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Altered cell shape

 

Necrosis and apoptosis are two distinct types of cell death, each with its own characteristics.

 

Altered cell shape: While cell shape can change in both necrosis and apoptosis, it is not a reliable indicator to differentiate between the two. The more useful parameter is cell size: in necrosis, cells swell, whereas in apoptosis, cells shrink. Therefore, altered cell shape is not particularly helpful in distinguishing necrosis from apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intact cell organelle: During apoptosis, cell organelles remain intact until the late stages when apoptotic bodies form. These bodies contain tightly packed cytoplasmic components and organelles. In contrast, necrosis is characterized by the breakdown and disintegration of organelles. Thus, the presence of intact organelles helps differentiate apoptosis from necrosis.

 

Option C. Enzyme mediated degradation: This is a hallmark of necrosis. In necrosis, enzymes digest cellular components, leading to the breakdown of organelles and other structures. This feature is not seen in apoptosis, where cellular components are typically preserved until the cell is packaged into apoptotic bodies.

 

Option D. Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change: Necrosis involves the disintegration of organelles and changes in lipids, leading to the loss of cell membrane integrity. This is not a feature of apoptosis, where the membrane remains intact until late stages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key features to differentiate necrosis from apoptosis include the state of cell organelles (intact in apoptosis, disintegrated in necrosis), enzyme-mediated degradation (present in necrosis), and internal organelle disintegration with lipid changes (present in necrosis). Altered cell shape alone is not a useful parameter for differentiation.

questions.text: An adult presented with pallor, fatigue and reduced work capacity.  His investigations revealed low RBC count, low hemoglobin, MCV 70fL and MCH24pg. which of the following is the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by low RBC count, low hemoglobin, and microcytic hypochromic indices (MCV < 80 fl and MCH < 27 pg). The patient’s symptoms of pallor, fatigue, and reduced work capacity are typical of anemia. The lab findings of MCV 70 fl (microcytic) and MCH 24 pg (hypochromic) are consistent with iron deficiency anemia, the most common type of anemia worldwide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folate deficiency: Causes macrocytic anemia (MCV > 100 fl), which is not consistent with the patient's lab results.

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease: Typically presents with normocytic or slightly microcytic anemia. However, iron deficiency anemia is more common and fits better with the lab findings.

 

Option C. Anemia due to renal failure: Usually presents with normocytic anemia, where the MCV is within the normal range (80-100 fl), not microcytic.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the most radiosensitive phase of a cell cycle? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) G2M

 

The cell cycle consists of several phases, including the quiescent phase (G0), G1 phase, S phase, G2 phase, and M phase.

 

The G2/M phase of the cell cycle is the most radiosensitive. This phase is critical for cell division, involving DNA repair mechanisms and the process of mitosis. Radiosensitivity is heightened due to the cells’ high mitotic activity and the presence of condensed chromosomes, which are more susceptible to damage by radiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S phase: Cells are synthesizing DNA and are somewhat resistant to radiation because DNA repair enzymes are active. S phase is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle.

 

Option C. M phase: Although mitosis is a rapid process, its radiosensitivity is slightly less than G2/M phase.

 

Option D. G1 phase: This phase involves the growth and preparation of the cell for DNA synthesis; cells in G1 are less sensitive to radiation compared to G2/M.

 

Note – Phases of cell cycle –

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Myxoid liposarcoma
Spindle lipoma

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with a retroperitoneal mass. Biopsy from the lesion is shown in the image below. Molecular analysis revealed t(12;16). What is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myxoid liposarcoma

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myxoid liposarcoma.

 

The image shows a lot of ground substance, as well as some branching capillaries and immature adipocytes.

 

Liposarcoma is the most common sarcoma in adults, typically appearing in the fifth to sixth decade of life.

 

They are most commonly found in the proximal extremities (deep soft tissues) and the retroperitoneum.

 

Histologically the liposarcomas are divided into four subtypes: 

 

  • Well-differentiated liposarcoma: resembles lipoma but contains uni- or multi-vacuolated lipoblasts. It is associated with amplification of 12q13-g15.
  • Myxoid liposarcoma: Most common histologic type. It is composed of monomorphic, fusiform or stellate cells representing primitive mesenchymal cells, lying dispersed in mucopolysaccharide-rich ground substance. Occasional tumor giant cells may be present. Prominent meshwork of capillaries forming chicken-wire patterns is a conspicuous feature. It is associated with t (12;16).
  • Round cell liposarcoma is composed of uniform, round to oval cells having fine multi vacuolated cytoplasm with central hyperchromatic nuclei. Round cell liposarcoma may resemble a signet-ring carcinoma but mucin stains help in distinguishing the two.
  • Pleomorphic liposarcoma: highly undifferentiated and the most anaplastic type. There are numerous large tumor giant cells and bizarre lipoblasts. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lipoma: This is incorrect. Lipomas are benign tumors of adipose tissue and do not show the histological features or molecular translocation (t (12;16)) seen in myxoid liposarcoma.

 

Option C. Spindle lipoma: This is incorrect. Spindle cell lipomas are benign tumors composed of spindle-shaped cells mixed with mature adipocytes and do not have the mucopolysaccharide-rich ground substance or the t (12;16) translocation seen in myxoid liposarcoma.

 

Option D. Polymorphic lipoma: This is incorrect. Polymorphic lipomas are also benign and do not exhibit the characteristic histological features or molecular markers of myxoid liposarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myxoid liposarcoma is the most common histologic type of liposarcoma, characterized by a mucopolysaccharide-rich ground substance, a prominent capillary network forming chicken-wire patterns, and the presence of the translocation t (12;16).

questions.text: Identify the condition represented in the image below: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Miliary tuberculosis

 

The above image represents “miliary tuberculosis”. Individual lesions are small (2-mm) foci of yellow-white consolidation scattered through the lung parenchyma.

 

Miliary tuberculosis is lymphohematogenous spread of tuberculous infection from primary focus or later stages of tuberculosis. The spread may occur to systemic organs or isolated organ. The spread is either by entry of infection into pulmonary vein producing disseminated or isolated organ lesion in different extra-pulmonary sites (e.g. liver, spleen, kidney, brain and bone marrow) or into pulmonary artery restricting the development of miliary lesions within the lung. The miliary lesions are millet seed-sized (1 mm diameter), yellowish, firm areas without grossly visible caseation necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emphysema: This condition is characterized by the abnormal, permanent enlargement of airspaces distal to the terminal bronchioles and the destruction of the alveolar walls. Large subpleural bullae (air-filled spaces >1 cm) may be present, especially in paraseptal emphysema.

 

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Typically presents with non-caseating granulomas.

 

 

Option D. Asbestosis: Associated with fibrous thickening and plaque formation primarily in the lung bases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Miliary tuberculosis appears as small, millet seed-sized yellowish foci scattered throughout the lung parenchyma, indicative of widespread hematogenous dissemination of tuberculosis.

questions.text: An individual undergoes a bone marrow examination which shows the presence of the cells as shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely enzyme defect associated with this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

 

The presence of gaucher cells with a crumpled paper appearance is suggestive of Gaucher’s disease. It is caused by deficiency of glucocerebrosidase.

 

Gaucher's Disease:

 

  • Pathology: Gaucher's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glucocerebroside into glucose and ceramide.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and bone pain or fractures.
  • Histopathology: Gaucher cells are macrophages filled with lipid-laden lysosomes. These cells have a characteristic crumpled paper appearance due to the accumulation of glucocerebroside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hexosaminidase: Deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by a cherry-red spot on the macula.

 

Option C. Alpha 1,4 glucosidase: Deficiency causes Pompe disease, characterized by glycogen accumulation in lysosomes.

 

Option D. Galactosidase: Deficiency causes Fabry disease, characterized by angiokeratomas, acroparesthesia, and renal failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher cells with a crumpled paper appearance in a bone marrow examination are indicative of Gaucher's disease, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

 

Gaucher Disease Overview:

questions.text: Identify the factor 'L' which combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX in given coagulation cascade? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor VII

 

The factor marked as 'L' is factor VII, which combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX.

 

 

Thrombin also activates factor XIlI, which is the fibrin stabilizing factor to factor XIlla. This factor XIlla forms covalent cross-links and thereby stabilizes the fibrin clot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor XII: Involved in the initiation of the intrinsic pathway, but it does not combine with tissue factor.

 

Option C. Factor VIII: Works as a cofactor for Factor IXa in the intrinsic pathway, but it does not combine with tissue factor.

 

Option D. VWF (Von Willebrand Factor): Involved in platelet adhesion and stabilization of Factor VIII but is not involved in the activation of the coagulation cascade by tissue factor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor VII is the key clotting factor that combines with tissue factor to activate Factor IX and Factor X, playing a crucial role in the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.

choices.text: 12 hours
24 hours
6 hours

questions.text: What is the maximum duration for TRALI to occur after blood transfusion? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6 hours

 

The maximum duration for TRALI (transfusion-related acute lung injury) to occur after blood transfusion is 6 hours.

 

TRALI is characterized as sudden onset respiratory failure that occurs during or shortly after a blood transfusion. The pathogenesis is based on a two-hit hypothesis:

 

  • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the lung microvasculature
  • Second knock - the factor (most commonly MHC class I antigens) present in the transfused blood product stimulates the primed neutrophils

 

Pathogenesis of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI):

 

  1. Dysregulation of Inflammatory Process: This indicates an imbalance or dysregulation in the normal inflammatory response.
  2. Leukocyte Antigen (Ag) Recipient: Refers to the recipient's leukocytes, which play a role in the immune response.
  3. Blood AB Donor: Indicates the presence of antibodies (AB) in the donated blood.
  4. First Hit: Represents an initial insult or trigger such as trauma, sepsis, or neutrophil activation that can activate the immune system.
  5. Endothelial Permeability: Describes the increased permeability of endothelial cells lining blood vessels.
  6. Second Hit: Refers to a secondary insult, which in this case is the transfusion of blood components.
  7. Transfusion Blood Components: Represents the infusion of blood products, including lysophosphatidylcholine (Lyso PC).
  8. Endothelial Activation: Activation of endothelial cells leading to cytokine release, which is the release of signalling molecules involved in immune responses.
  9. Common Pathway: Illustrates that both the first hit and the second hit converge to activate a common pathway.
  10. Alveolar Capillary Pulmonary Damage: Indicates the injury and damage occurring in the alveolar-capillary membrane in the lungs.
  11. Acute Respiratory Failure: Refers to the development of sudden respiratory distress and failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TRALI vs TACO: -

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given serum electrophoresis image (pink)? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nephrotic syndrome

 

The given electrophoresis picture shows hypoalbuminemia and increased alpha-2 globulin, which is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma would typically present with a sharp, monoclonal spike in the gamma region (known as an M-spike or paraprotein spike) due to the overproduction of a single type of immunoglobulin by malignant plasma cells. This pattern is not seen in the provided electrophoresis image.

 

Option B. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis is generally associated with a chronic inflammatory response and can show a polyclonal increase in the gamma region due to chronic immune activation. However, it does not show the specific hypoalbuminemia and alpha-2 globulin increase seen in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option C. Hepatic cirrhosis: In hepatic cirrhosis, the electrophoresis pattern often shows a polyclonal increase in the gamma region (polyclonal gammopathy), sometimes with a beta-gamma bridging pattern. This pattern is not consistent with the hypoalbuminemia and alpha-2 globulin increase observed in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The electrophoresis pattern showing hypoalbuminemia combined with an increase in alpha-2 globulin is most indicative of nephrotic syndrome, reflecting the characteristic loss of albumin and retention of larger plasma proteins in this condition.

questions.text: Amyloidosis associated with transthyretin deposition is: (NEET 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Senile systemic amyloidosis

 

Explanation:

 

Senile systemic amyloidosis is characterized by the deposition of Transthyretin (TTR) in its wild-type form in the heart and other organs of the elderly. This form of amyloidosis is distinct from other types as it involves a normal serum protein (TTR) that binds and transports thyroxine and retinol, rather than a mutated protein or a protein associated with inflammation or dialysis-related conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma: Associated with AL amyloidosis, not transthyretin deposition.

 

Option B. Hemodialysis: Associated with β2-microglobulin amyloidosis (Aβ2m), not TTR.

 

Option C. Familial Mediterranean fever: Typically leads to AA amyloidosis due to inflammation, not TTR-related amyloidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Senile systemic amyloidosis involves the deposition of normal Transthyretin (TTR) protein, primarily affecting the heart and occurring predominantly in the elderly

questions.text: Cancer that least commonly spreads by lymphatic route is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Basal Cell Carcinoma

 

Basal cell carcinoma is a locally aggressive tumor that rarely spreads by the lymphatic route.

 

Mutations in sonic hedgehog pathway are associated with it.

 

Grossly, the most common pattern is a nodulo-ulcerative basal cell carcinoma in which a slow-growing small nodule undergoes central ulceration with pearly, rolled margins.

 

 

The occasional presence of melanin in this variant of nodular BCC (pigmented BCC. may lead to confusion with melanoma.

 

It occurs exclusively on hairy skin, the most common location (90%) being the face, usually above a line from the lobe of the ear to the corner of the mouth. The most common site is the inner canthus of the eye.

 

 

Basal cell carcinoma does not show lymphatic or hematogenous metastasis. It is primarily locally invasive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma often spreads via the lymphatic system, particularly when occurring in the skin or mucous membranes.

 

Option B. Merkel Cell Carcinoma: This is a rare and aggressive form of skin cancer that frequently metastasizes via the lymphatic system.

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma: Melanoma is known for its high metastatic potential, often spreading through both lymphatic and hematogenous routes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal cell carcinoma is primarily a locally invasive tumor that rarely spreads via the lymphatic or hematogenous routes, distinguishing it from other more aggressive skin cancers.

questions.text: A girl presents with short stature, webbed neck, thick calves, shield -shaped chest, swelling of the ankle, and increased carrying angle. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

 

The constellation of symptoms including short stature, webbed neck, thick calves, shield-shaped chest, swelling of the ankles, and increased carrying angle is suggestive of Turner syndrome.

 

Turner syndrome is caused by complete or partial X-chromosome monosomy. In phenotypic females, it causes hypogonadism. In females, it is the most common sex chromosome abnormality.

 

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome:

 

  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Streak ovaries, infertility, amenorrhea
  • Peripheral lymphedema at birth
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Pigmented nevi
  • Coarctation of aorta

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Down syndrome: (Trisomy 21) is characterized by intellectual disability, facial dysmorphism, and increased risk of certain medical conditions such as congenital heart defects and leukemia.

 

Option C. Patau syndrome: (Trisomy 13): characterised by severe intellectual disability, cleft lip/palate, polydactyly, microcephaly, congenital heart defects, and often leads to early infant mortality.

 

Option D. Edward syndrome: (Trisomy 18) characterised by severe intellectual disability, micrognathia (small jaw), clenched fists with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, congenital heart defects, and also typically results in early infant mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, shield-shaped chest, peripheral lymphedema, and increased carrying angle, among other physical manifestations. It is caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome in phenotypic females.

questions.text: ALK positivity is seen in which of the following neoplasms: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor

 

ALK (anaplastic lymphoma kinase) is seen in Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor of lung.

 

(ALK) Anaplastic lymphoma kinase {CD246} is a tyrosine kinase receptor encoded by the ALK gene located on chromosome 2p

 

ALK positive tumors respond to ALK kinase inhibitors, therefore it has an excellent prognosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibromatosis: ALK positivity is not associated with fibromatosis. This condition is characterized by fibroblastic proliferation, and ALK is not typically involved.

 

Option B. Synovial sarcoma: Synovial sarcoma does not show ALK positivity. It is more often associated with specific translocations, such as t(X;18)(p11;q11), resulting in SS18-SSX fusion genes.

 

Option C. Ewing sarcoma: Ewing sarcoma is characterized by a specific EWSR1-FLI1 fusion gene due to a translocation involving chromosomes 11 and 22. ALK positivity is not seen in Ewing sarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ALK positivity is seen in:

 

  • Lung Cancers – Adenocarcinoma, small cell cancer, anaplastic cancer
  • Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Renal cell carcinomas
  • Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma
  • Breast cancer notably the inflammatory subtype
  • Colonic adenocarcinoma
  • Glioblastoma multiforme
  • Anaplastic thyroid cancer

choices.text: It is detected in blood during sepsis
It is produced in response to bacterial infection.
It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding neutrophil extracellular trapping (NET)? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitochondrial DNA is seen

 

Mitochondrial DNA is not seen in neutrophil extracellular traps (NET). In classic NETosis, the DNA is nuclear, not mitochondrial.

 

Some rare reports suggest that under certain non-lytic forms, mitochondrial DNA may be extruded, but this is not typical of NETs as understood in bacterial infections or sepsis.

 

Neutrophilic extracellular traps (NET) are a network of neutrophil nuclear chromatin/DNA. The death of neutrophils is caused by the loss of nuclei. They assemble antimicrobial peptides and enzymes to combat bacteria and fungi (not viruses). During sepsis, they are detected in the blood.

 

They are produced by neutrophils in response to:

 

  • Infectious pathogens: mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators: chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is detected in blood during sepsis:

 

  • True Statement: NETs are indeed detected in the blood during sepsis as part of the body's response to widespread infection.

 

Option B. It is produced in response to bacterial infection:

 

  • True Statement: NETs are produced in response to bacterial infection as well as fungal infections.

 

Option D. It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes:

 

  • True Statement: NETs consist of chromatin (DNA) along with antibacterial enzymes and peptides, which help in trapping and killing pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are networks of nuclear DNA from neutrophils combined with antimicrobial enzymes and peptides, produced in response to bacterial and fungal infections. They play a crucial role in trapping and neutralizing pathogens. The presence of mitochondrial DNA in NETs is incorrect, as NETs are composed of nuclear chromatin.

choices.text: Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element increases and ferritin synthesis decreases
Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis
Transferrin receptor 1 iron responsive elements decreases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis
Ferritin mRNA concentration iron responsive element decreases and ferritin synthesis increases

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the internal iron homeostasis in iron-deficiency anemia? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis

 

In iron deficiency anemia, there is an increase in transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis.

 

 

Progressive depletion of iron reserves first lowers serum iron and transferrin saturation levels without producing anemia. In this early stage there is increased erythroid activity in the bone marrow.

 

Anemia appears only when iron stores are completely depleted and is accompanied by low serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation levels.

 

The serum iron and ferritin are low, and the total plasma iron-binding capacity (reflecting elevated transferrin levels) is high. Low serum iron with increased iron-binding capacity results in a reduction of transferrin saturation to below 15%. Reduced iron stores inhibit hepcidin synthesis, and its serum levels fall and this in turn facilitates iron absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element increases and ferritin synthesis decreases: This statement is incorrect. In iron deficiency, ferritin synthesis decreases as the body conserves iron, but the ferritin mRNA concentration does not increase.

 

Option C. Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements decreases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis: This is incorrect because in iron deficiency, transferrin receptor 1 expression increases to maximize iron uptake.

 

Option D. Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element decreases and ferritin synthesis increases: This is also incorrect. In iron deficiency, both ferritin mRNA levels and ferritin synthesis decrease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In iron-deficiency anemia, transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increase mRNA concentration and synthesis to enhance iron uptake, while ferritin levels decrease as the body attempts to conserve iron.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, pg 1231-1234

questions.text: A 60-year-old with lower backache had low hemoglobin, increased creatinine and multiple osteolytic lesions on radiograph. His serum electrophoresis revealed normal albumin but disproportionately high globulin. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple myeloma

 

The clinical picture presented is suggestive of anemia, renal dysfunction and bony lytic lesions with increased production of globulin levels suggestive of monoclonal proliferation of plasma cells and meeting the CRAB criteria of multiple myeloma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prostate cancer: Prostate cancer can present with bone pain due to metastasis, but it typically causes sclerotic (rather than osteolytic) bone lesions and does not cause the marked increase in globulin levels seen in multiple myeloma.

 

Option C. Pott's spine: This refers to tuberculosis of the spine and can present with back pain and osteolytic lesions, but it is not associated with increased globulin levels or the hematological findings seen in multiple myeloma.

 

Option D. Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis can cause bone pain and fractures but does not cause anemia, renal dysfunction, or increased globulin levels.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Multiple myeloma is characterized by anemia, renal dysfunction, osteolytic bone lesions, and a high globulin level due to monoclonal proliferation of plasma cells.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, with a smoking history of 20 pack years, presented in OPD with breathlessness and chest pain. Further investigations revealed a lung tumor. On staining, cells are positive for chromogranin. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Small cell carcinoma 

 

History of chronic smoking and lung tumor cells staining positive for chromogranin suggests small cell carcinoma of the lung.

 

SMALL CELL CARCINOMAS:

 

  1. This highly malignant tumor has a distinctive cell type.
  2. Strongly associated with cigarette smoking
  3. This lung cancer type is most commonly associated with ectopic hormone production
  4. Electron microscopy shows
    • Dense-core neurosecretory granules are present along the bronchial epithelium which can secrete polypeptide hormones
    • Presence of neuroendocrine markers such as chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD57 (in 75% of cases) and parathormone-like and other hormonally active products suggest derivation of this tumor from neuroendocrine progenitor cells of the lining bronchial epithelium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenocarcinoma: This is the most common subtype of lung cancer, especially in non-smokers, and it typically involves peripheral lung lesions. It is characterized by markers like TTF-1, NAPSIN-A, and CEA, rather than chromogranin.

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type is also associated with smoking but is more likely to present centrally in the lungs. It shows keratinization and intercellular bridges on histology and is associated with markers like p40 and p63, not chromogranin.

 

Option C. Large cell carcinoma: This diagnosis is typically a diagnosis of exclusion and does not have a specific marker like chromogranin. It is also more common in non-smokers and presents as a peripheral tumor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Hepatitis B virus

questions.text: Donor blood should be screened for the following infections except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dengue virus

 

Dengue virus is not typically included in the mandatory screening process for blood donations. While dengue is a significant public health issue, particularly in tropical and subtropical regions, its transmission through blood transfusion is rare and not considered a primary risk compared to the other pathogens listed.

 

Other Options:
