Option A. Hepatitis C virus: This virus is a common cause of liver disease and is a bloodborne pathogen. Blood donations are routinely screened for HCV to prevent transmission through transfusion.

 

Option C. Human immunodeficiency virus: HIV is a critical pathogen to screen for in donated blood because it can be transmitted through blood transfusion and is responsible for causing AIDS.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B virus: Like HCV, HBV is a major bloodborne pathogen that can lead to serious liver disease. Blood is routinely screened for HBV to ensure it is safe for transfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Donor blood require screening for infectious disease pathogen:

 

  • Hepatitis C virus
  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  • Hepatitis B virus
  • Malaria 
  • Syphilis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents annually with recurrent episodes of wheezing, cough, and difficulty breathing during a specific season. She has a history of seasonal allergies and reports exacerbations triggered by pollen exposure. Laboratory tests show elevated serum IgE levels, and she experiences rapid onset of symptoms shortly after exposure to the allergen. Which of the following cells is primarily responsible for the acute symptoms observed in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mast cells

 

Explanation:

 

This patient’s symptoms are characteristic of seasonal allergic asthma, which is a type I hypersensitivity reaction. The key feature here is the rapid onset of symptoms (wheezing, cough, and shortness of breath) shortly after exposure to an allergen (e.g., pollen), which points to an immediate-type hypersensitivity reaction. In this type of allergic reaction, mast cells play a central role.

 

  • Mast cells (Option A) are the primary effector cells in Type I hypersensitivity reactions. When the patient’s IgE (Option C) binds to mast cells, it sensitizes them. Upon subsequent exposure to the allergen, mast cells degranulate and release histamine and other mediators that cause the acute symptoms (such as bronchoconstriction and mucosal inflammation).
  • Eosinophils (Option B) are involved in the late-phase inflammatory response (the chronic phase) of asthma and allergies, but they are not responsible for the acute symptoms in this case.
  • IgE (Option C) is critical in sensitizing mast cells but does not directly cause the symptoms itself. It binds to mast cells, and when the allergen interacts with the IgE, it triggers mast cell degranulation.
  • Neutrophils (Option D) are involved in Type III hypersensitivity reactions and infections, but they are not central to the allergic responses seen in asthma.

 

Educational Objective:


In Type I hypersensitivity reactions (like allergic asthma), mast cells are the key players responsible for the acute symptoms, with IgE being crucial for mast cell sensitization.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents with 400 ml urine output in 24 hours. On histology he had crescents with pauci immune glomerulonephritis. What is the main etiology? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ANCA

 

The presence of crescents in a pauci-immune glomerulonephritis pattern is characteristic of ANCA-associated vasculitis. This type of vasculitis does not typically involve immune deposits (hence "pauci-immune") and is commonly associated with anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). These antibodies are directed against constituents of neutrophil granules and monocyte lysosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti GBM antibody: This antibody targets the glomerular basement membrane, leading to Goodpasture's syndrome, which is typically not pauci-immune.

 

Option C. Anti-phospholipase A2 receptor antibody: This is primarily associated with primary membranous nephropathy, which shows a different histological pattern.

 

Option D. Anti-nuclear antibody: While antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus, which can involve the kidneys, lupus nephritis usually shows immune complex deposition, unlike pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ANCA-associated vasculitis is linked to pauci-immune glomerulonephritis, where crescents are formed in glomeruli without significant immune deposits, differentiating it from conditions such as Goodpasture's syndrome or lupus nephritis.

questions.text: A 20-year old male patient is presenting with hematuria and hemoptysis. On further testing Anti glomerular basement membrane antibody is positive, what will be the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Goodpasture syndrome

 

  • Given clinical scenario is suggestive of good pasture syndrome as patient is presenting with hematuria and hemoptysis along with Anti glomerular basement membrane antibody.
  • It is type 2 hypersensitivity reaction
  • It belongs to type 1 RPGN
  • The autoantibodies are directed against the alpha 3 chain of collagen IV and predominantly belong to the IgG group. This immunofluorescence pattern shows positivity with antibody to IgG and has a smooth, diffuse, linear pattern that is characteristic for deposition of glomerular basement membrane antibody with Goodpasture syndrome. Serologic testing for anti-GBM in patient serum is often positive.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glomerular nephropathy: This is a general term for diseases affecting the glomeruli, but it does not specifically fit the provided clinical scenario.

 

Option C. Glomerulonephritis: While Goodpasture syndrome is a type of glomerulonephritis, the specific presence of anti-GBM antibodies and the combination of hematuria and hemoptysis point directly to Goodpasture syndrome.

 

Option D. Alport’s syndrome: This is a genetic disorder characterized by glomerulonephritis, end-stage kidney disease, and hearing loss, and it does not typically present with anti-GBM antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Goodpasture syndrome is characterized by the presence of anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies, hematuria, and hemoptysis, and is a type II hypersensitivity reaction associated with type I Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN).

questions.text: A farmer had a lesion on his shoulder. Histopathological image of the lesion is shown below. Identify the diagnosis: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squamous Cell Carcinoma

 

The histopathological image provided shows features consistent with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). The key characteristics that support this diagnosis are the presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges.

 

Keratin pearls are concentric, whorl-like structures composed of keratinized cells, which are a hallmark of well-differentiated SCC. The presence of keratin indicates that the tumor cells are undergoing a process of keratinization, which is a characteristic feature of squamous epithelium. In the image, the pink, circular structures with a laminated appearance are keratin pearls.

 

Intercellular bridges, also known as desmosomes, are specialized cell junctions that connect adjacent squamous epithelial cells. These bridges help maintain the structural integrity of the epithelium and are visible as small, spiky projections between the tumor cells in the image.

 

The occupation of the patient (farmer) is also relevant, as prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight is a major risk factor for the development of SCC, particularly on sun-exposed areas like the shoulder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is another type of skin cancer that arises from the basal layer of the epidermis. However, BCC typically lacks keratinization and the formation of keratin pearls, which are seen in this image.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum: Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by a poxvirus. Histologically, it is characterized by the presence of molluscum bodies, which are large, eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions within the keratinocytes. These features are not seen in the provided image.

 

Option D. Verrucous carcinoma: Verrucous carcinoma is a rare, low-grade variant of SCC that typically presents as a warty, exophytic growth. While it may show some keratinization, the classic keratin pearls and intercellular bridges seen in this image are more suggestive of conventional SCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges in a skin biopsy is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma, particularly in a patient with a history of prolonged sun exposure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the genetics of G6PD Deficiency is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Contradicts the Lyon Hypothesis.

 

Explanation: 

 

G6PD deficiency follows an X-linked inheritance pattern, with the gene located on the X chromosome. The Lyon hypothesis (X-chromosome inactivation) actually explains why some heterozygous females can be affected by G6PD deficiency, though typically less severely than males. During early embryonic development, one X chromosome in each female cell is randomly inactivated. If a higher proportion of cells have the normal X chromosome inactivated, these females can express symptoms of G6PD deficiency. This variable inactivation creates a mosaic pattern in heterozygous females rather than contradicting the hypothesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-linked inheritance - This is correct. G6PD deficiency is indeed an X-linked recessive disorder, which places males at much higher risk for symptomatic disease.

 

Option B. More severe in males - This is correct. Since males have only one X chromosome, if they inherit the defective G6PD gene, they will express the disorder fully, making the condition typically more severe in males.

 

Option D. May affect heterozygous females - This is correct. Heterozygous females can be affected due to random X-inactivation, where some cells express the defective G6PD gene, potentially leading to clinical manifestations.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that follows the principles of the Lyon hypothesis, with males being more severely affected, while heterozygous females may show variable expression depending on X-chromosome inactivation patterns.

choices.text: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient has proteinuria. Looking at the immunofluorescence image below, what is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lupus nephritis

 

The given immunofluorescence staining of the kidney biopsy specimen shows positive staining for fibrinogen, IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, λ chain, and k light chain. This is known as full-house effect. It is seen in lupus nephritis.

 

Six patterns of lupus nephritis

 

  1. Class I - Minimal lesions - deposits within the mesangium positive for IgG and C3.
  2. Class II – Mesangial lupus nephritis - Granular mesangial deposits of IgG and C3; sometimes IgA and IgM are also present in the deposits.
  3. Class III – Focal segmental lupus nephritis - Subendothelial and subepithelial deposits of IgG, often with IgM or IgA and C3, are seen.
  4. Class IV – Diffuse lupus nephritis – Most severe and most common. Deposits in the mesangium and in the subendothelial region which on immunofluorescence are positive for IgG; sometimes also for IgA or IgM, and C3.
  5. Class V – Membranous Lupus Nephritis - subendothelial deposits of immune complexes containing IgG, IgM and C3
  6. Class VI – Sclerosing Lupus nephritis - End-stage kidney of SLE. Most glomeruli are sclerosed and hyalinised and there may be remnants of preceding lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): This does not typically show a full-house pattern on immunofluorescence. FSGS is usually characterized by segmental glomerular scarring and may show focal deposits of IgM and C3.

 

Option B. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSG): This condition typically shows deposits of IgG and C3 in a "starry sky" pattern on immunofluorescence but does not display a full-house pattern.

 

Option C. Goodpasture syndrome: This typically shows linear deposits of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane, without the full-house pattern seen in lupus nephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The full-house effect on immunofluorescence (positive staining for IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, λ chain, and κ light chain) is a hallmark of lupus nephritis.

 

Ref: Robbins Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition, Pg 409-410

choices.text: Tests reveals elevated serum calcitonin levels
Most patients have a good prognosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not the correct statement about papillary thyroid cancer? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tests reveals elevated serum calcitonin levels

 

Papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) is the most common type of thyroid cancer and generally has a good prognosis. It is often associated with a history of radiation exposure, and it commonly affects individuals in their early third decade (20s-30s). However, elevated serum calcitonin levels are not a feature of PTC; this finding is specific to medullary thyroid cancer (MTC), which arises from the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid and produces calcitonin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. History of radiation exposure: This is a known risk factor for the development of PTC.

 

Option B. Affects in early third decade: PTC commonly presents in young adults, particularly in the third decade of life.

 

Option D. Most patients have a good prognosis: PTC generally has an excellent prognosis, especially when diagnosed early and treated appropriately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary thyroid cancer is not associated with elevated serum calcitonin levels; this is a characteristic feature of medullary thyroid cancer.

questions.text: An affected male does not have affected children, but 50% of the offspring of an affected female are affected. Which of the following is the likely pattern of inheritance in the given situation. (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) X-linked recessive

 

Explanation:

 

X-linked recessive inheritance is a pattern in which a gene located on the X chromosome causes a condition that can affect both males and females. The distinguishing feature of X-linked recessive inheritance is that affected males cannot pass the trait to their sons (since males pass only the Y chromosome to their sons), but they pass it to all of their daughters making them carriers. However an affected female is going to have both the genes defective and shall have all her sons having the disease and all her daughters acting as carriers..

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Autosomal recessive: Incorrect. Autosomal recessive conditions require both parents to pass on a copy of the mutated gene, leading to equal chances of affecting both sexes.

 

Option C. X-linked dominant: Incorrect. Affected males pass the condition to all daughters but not to their sons. Affected females pass the condition to 50% of their offspring (both sons and daughters).

 

Option D. Mitochondrial: Incorrect. Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by maternal transmission, where affected males do not pass the trait, but all offspring of affected females inherit it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In X-linked recessive inheritance, males are more frequently affected, and females are typically carriers. Affected males do not pass the condition to their sons, but daughters may become carriers.

questions.text: Gamma delta T cell receptors (γδ TCRs) recognizes? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lipids without MHC proteins

 

  • A small population of mature T cells expresses a type of TCR composed of γ and δ polypeptide chains. The γδ TCR recognizes peptides, lipids, and small molecules, without a requirement for display by MHC proteins. γδ T cells tend to aggregate at epithelial surfaces, such as the skin and mucosa of the gastrointestinal and urogenital tracts, suggesting that these cells are sentinels that protect against microbes that try to enter through epithelia
  • The αβ TCR recognizes peptide antigens that are displayed by major histocompatibility complex (MHC. molecules on the surfaces of antigen-presenting cells (APCs). By limiting the specificity of T cells for peptides displayed by cell surface MHC molecules, called MHC restriction, the immune system ensures that T cells see only cell-associated antigens (e.g., those derived from microbes in cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Peptides with MHC proteins: This is characteristic of αβ TCRs, not γδ TCRs.

 

Option C. CD20: CD20 is a B cell marker, not a target recognized by T cell receptors.

 

Option D. CD3: CD3 is a signaling molecule associated with the T cell receptor complex but is not a specific target recognized by the TCR itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma delta T cell receptors (γδ TCRs) are unique in that they can recognize lipids and other molecules without the need for MHC protein presentation, distinguishing them from the more common αβ T cells.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 353

questions.text: A person working in an industry for a long time developed progressive breathlessness. The histopathological image of his lung biopsy is given below. What industry was he most likely working in? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asbestos

 

From the clinical history of progressive breathlessness and the histopathological image showing asbestos bodies, ferruginous bodies, and fibrosis, the patient is most likely working in the asbestos industry.

 

Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure. The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility. This condition is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis.

 

Grossly, the affected lungs are small and firm with cartilage-like thickening of the pleura.

 

 

The sectioned surface shows variable degree of pulmonary fibrosis, especially in the subpleural areas and in the bases of lungs. The advanced cases may show cystic changes.

 

 

Gross appearance of the lung in asbestosis diagram

 

Histologically, the following changes are observed:

 

  • There is non-specific interstitial fibrosis.
  • There is presence of characteristic asbestos bodies in the involved areas. These are asbestos fibres coated with glycoprotein and haemosiderin and appear beaded or dumbbell-shaped. The coating stains positively for Prussian blue reaction. Similar iron-protein complexes coat other inorganic particulates other than asbestos which are termed as ferruginous bodies.

 

Microscopic appearance of asbestos body. An asbestos body is an asbestos fibre coated with glycoprotein and haemosiderin giving it beaded or dumbbell-shaped appearance with bulbous ends.

 

Note: Asbestos exposure is associated with malignant mesothelioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silica: Silica exposure leads to silicosis, which is characterized by nodular fibrosis, not asbestos bodies.

 

Option C. Coal dust: Coal dust exposure leads to coal workers' pneumoconiosis (CWP) or "black lung disease," characterized by coal macules and nodules in the lungs.

 

Option D. Cotton: Cotton dust exposure leads to byssinosis, which is primarily associated with respiratory symptoms but does not cause the fibrosis and asbestos bodies seen in asbestosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is associated with the presence of asbestos bodies and interstitial fibrosis, typically seen in individuals working in industries involving asbestos exposure.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition 1306-1307

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial infections and Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia. The flowcytometry analysis of the boy (Boxes c & d) is shown below (Boxes a & b are normal). What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyper IgM syndrome

 

The given clinical scenario and the flow cytometry is suggestive of Hyper IgM syndrome. The flow cytometry shows the following findings:

 

  • B-cell gating (images a and c)
  • Side scatter (images b and d)
  • Decrease in the number of CD40 (image d)

 

In hyper-IgM syndrome the affected patients make IgM antibodies but are deficient in their ability to produce IgG, IgA, and IgE antibodies. The ability of helper T cells to deliver activating signals to B cells and macrophages is affected. Many of the functions of CD4+ helper T cells require the engagement of CD40 on B cells, macrophages and dendritic cells by CD40L (also called CD154) expressed on antigen-activated T cells. This interaction triggers Ig class switching and affinity maturation in B cells, and stimulates the microbicidal functions of macrophages.

 

Most of these patients have mutations in the gene encoding CD40 or the enzyme called activation-induced deaminase, a DNA-editing cytosine deaminase that is required for class switching and affinity maturation.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bare lymphocytes: This refers to a rare genetic condition where major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules are not expressed on the surface of cells, leading to immune deficiency. This condition is unrelated to the findings presented in the question.

 

Option B. Chronic granulocyte deficiency: This refers to Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD), a condition where phagocytes cannot effectively kill certain bacteria and fungi. It does not fit the flow cytometry or clinical presentation described in the question.

 

Option D. DiGeorge syndrome: DiGeorge syndrome is a congenital immunodeficiency due to the deletion of chromosome 22q11.2, leading to thymic hypoplasia and T cell deficiency. The clinical and flow cytometry findings in this question do not match those typically seen in DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper IgM syndrome is characterized by a deficiency in class switching due to defective CD40-CD40L interactions, leading to elevated levels of IgM and a lack of other immunoglobulin isotypes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease

 

Histopathological image shows acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis seen in Kimmelstiel Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

 

These lesions are specific for type 1 diabetes (juvenile onset diabetes) or islet cell antibody-positive diabetes mellitus.

 

The pathologic changes consist of one or more nodules in a few or many glomeruli. Nodule is an ovoid or spherical, laminated, hyaline, acellular mass located within a lobule of the glomerulus.

 

The nodules are surrounded peripherally by glomerular capillary loops which may have normal or thickened GBM. The nodules are PAS-positive and contain lipid and fibrin. These nodular lesions are frequently accompanied by prominent accumulations of hyaline material in capillary loops (“fibrin caps”) or adherent to Bowman's capsules (“capsular drops”).

 

 

As the nodular lesions enlarge, they compress the glomerular capillaries and obliterate the glomerular tuft. As a result of glomerular and arteriolar involvement, renal ischemia occurs leading to tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis and grossly small, contracted kidney.

 

Renal failure is the second common cause of death in diabetes mellitus, the first being myocardial infarction.

 

Diabetic nephropathy encompasses 4 types of renal lesions in diabetes mellitus:

 

1. Diabetic glomerulosclerosis (Diffuse/ Nodular)

 

  1. Diffuse lesions are characterized by diffuse involvement of the glomeruli showing thickening of the GBM and diffuse increase in the mesangial matrix with mild proliferation of mesangial cells and exudative lesions (fibrin caps and capsular drops)
  2. Nodular lesion (Kimmelstiel-Wilson Lesion) is characterized by one or more hyaline nodules within the lobules of glomeruli, surrounded peripherally by glomerular capillaries with thickened walls.

 

 

2.  Vascular lesions – Hyaline arterioslerosis

Morphology

 

 

3. Diabetic pyelonephritis – Papillary necrosis / Necrotizing papillitis

 

4. Tubular lesions (Armanni-Ebstein lesions).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal amyloidosis: Amyloidosis presents with amyloid deposits, typically visualized using Congo red stain, which is different from the PAS-positive nodules seen in Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease.

 

Option B. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): FSGS is characterized by segmental scarring of some glomeruli and does not present with the diffuse nodular glomerulosclerosis observed in Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease.

 

Option D. Lupus nephritis: Lupus nephritis involves immune complex deposition, which leads to a different set of histological changes, including "wire loop" lesions, which are not present in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease, a specific form of diabetic nephropathy, is characterized by PAS-positive nodules within the glomeruli, often associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 2206
